snippet: Moktada al-Sadr, the former leader of the anti-American Mahdi Army, is trying to navigate his way to national power through nontraditional alliances that risk alienating supporters.
abstract: Moktada al-Sadr, the populist Shiite leader, has emerged as a mainstream political leader looking to secure the claims to power that his movement achieved through violent opposition to the American occupation; he has returned from Iran, widely considered his patron, to attend to a political crisis in Iraq over contests for power among Shiites, Sunnis and Kurds that have brought the government to a standstill.

byline.contributor: Duraid Adnan contributed reporting from Najaf, and Yasir Ghazi from Baghdad.

lead_paragraph: Moktada al-Sadr, the former leader of the anti-American Mahdi Army, is trying to navigate his way to national power through nontraditional alliances that risk alienating supporters.

headline.seo: Moktada al-Sadr Recast as Political Insurgent in Iraq
headline.main: U.S. Antagonist in Iraq Takes a Political Gamble
headline.print_headline: U.S. Antagonist in Iraq Takes a Political Gamble
